questions.solution: Solution:		An anemometer is an instrument that measures wind speed and wind pressure. Anemometers are important tools for meteorologists, who study weather patterns.

questions.Question: A fountain pen works on the principle of
questions.optionA: Flow of liquids from higher to lower potential
questions.solution: Solution:		A fountain pen is a nib pen that, unlike its predecessor, the dip pen, contains an internal reservoir of liquid ink. The pen draws ink from the reservoir through a feed to the nib and deposits it on paper via a combination of gravity and capillary action.

questions.Question: A barometer is kept inside a bell jar. Air is slowly pumped out of the jar.
questions.optionC: The mercury level does not change
questions.solution: Solution:		As the pump removes the air from the bell jar the pressure obviously reduces around the barometer. The reduction in pressure around the barometer leads it to expand. As the pump removes air from the jar, the mercury level rises.

questions.Question: The temperature at which water boils depends mainly on
questions.solution: Solution:		The temperature at which water boils depends mainly on air pressure.

questions.Question: Air pressure is measured in which of the following units?
questions.solution: Solution:		Air pressure is measured in Pascal.

questions.Question: The quantity that is not conserved in an inelastic collision is
questions.solution: Solution:		Momentum is conserved in all types of collision whether it is elastic or inelastic where as kinetic energy is lost in sound energy in the absence of external force in inelastic collision.

questions.Question: The dimension MLT–2 corresponds to
questions.solution: Solution:		The dimensions of Force are M (mass), L (length) and T-2(time). It can also be expressed as [newton] = [kilogram] [metre] [second]-2.

questions.Question: If lift is going up with acceleration, the apparent weight of a body is
questions.optionA: May be more or less than true weight
questions.solution: Solution:		If lift is going up with acceleration, the apparent weight of a body is more than the true weight.

questions.Question: The force that generates wind is
questions.solution: Solution:		The force that generates wind is pressure gradient force.

questions.Question: A boy sitting in a train moving with a uniform velocity drops a coin outside. A man standing outside the train will find the trajectory of the coin to be
questions.solution: Solution:		Parabola, because when the coin is dropped at a particular point, it has the same velocity as the running train. So, by Newton's first law, it continues its motion horizontally with that velocity. But then, it is also pulled down by earth's gravity continuously. In this situation its horizontal motion gives way to the parabolic motion until it reaches the ground.

questions.Question: The rotational effect of a force on a body about an axis of rotation is described in terms of
questions.solution: Solution:		The rotational effect of a force on a body about an axis of rotation is described in terms of moment of force.

questions.Question: At hill stations, the boiling point of water will be
questions.optionB: Less than that at sea level
questions.optionC: More than that at sea level
questions.optionD: Equal to the melting point of ice
questions.solution: Solution:		The boiling point is the temperature at which the vapour pressure of the liquid equals the environmental pressure surrounding the liquid. Atmospheric pressure is due to air above any given point. The atmospheric pressure at high altitudes like hill station is less than at the sea level.Thus, vapour pressure will equal atmospheric pressure at a comparatively low temperature. Thus, the boiling point of water is reduced less than at sea level.

questions.Question: Instrument used to measure the force and velocity of the wind is
questions.solution: Solution:		An anemometer is a device used for measuring wind speed and direction. It is also a common weather station instrument.

questions.Question: When pressure is increased the melting point of ice
questions.optionD: Depends on the impurities in the ice
questions.solution: Solution:		The melting point of ice decreases when pressure increases because when pressure is increased volume is decreased and volume of water is less than ice.

questions.Question: The wall of a dam is made thicker at the bottom than at the top because the pressure exerted by the water on the wall
questions.optionA: Depends on the thickness of the wall
questions.optionB: Increases with height of the wall
questions.optionC: Increases with depth of the wall
questions.optionD: Depends on the area of the wall
questions.solution: Solution:		The pressure applied to walls of the dam will be a function of the amount of water that is over that particular point on the wall. So water pressure is very large at the bottom due to its large depth. That's why dams are constructed thicker at their bottoms than at their tops.

questions.Question: Skids occur when the brakes are applied so hard that the front or rear wheels lose traction are called as
questions.solution: Solution:		A skid happens whenever the tires lose their grip on the road. Braking skids occur when the brakes are applied so hard that the front or rear wheels lose traction.

questions.Question: During the motion of a projectile fired from the earth surface, ________
questions.optionC: Vertical component of its velocity remains constant
questions.optionD: Horizontal component of its velocity remains constant
questions.solution: Solution:		During the motion of a projectile fired from the earth surface, horizontal component of its velocity remains constant.

questions.Question: What property of matter is momentum related to?
questions.solution: Solution:		Momentum is related to mass and velocity.

questions.Question: The swing of a spinning cricket ball in air can be explained on the basis of
questions.solution: Solution:		The main theory of swing bowling surrounded turbulent and laminar airflow. Laminar air separates from the surface of the ball earlier than turbulent flow air, so that the separation point moves toward the front of the ball on the laminar side. On the turbulent flow side it remains towards the back; inducing a greater lift force on the turbulent airflow side of the ball. The calculated net lift force is not enough to account for the amount of swing observed: Additional force is provided by the pressure-gradient force.

questions.Question: What will happen if an object is dropped from a height and there is no air resistance?
questions.optionA: It will fall with a constant speed and acceleration
questions.optionC: Both speed and acceleration will increase
questions.solution: Solution:		If an object is dropped from a height and there is no air resistance its speed will increase.

questions.Question: A piece of ice is floating in water kept in a beaker. When all the ice melts the level of water will
questions.solution: Solution:		When a piece of ice is placed in a beaker containing water, some of its portion remains out of the water level. Since the volume of ice is greater than the water hence after melting the volume of the piece will decrease and the water level will remain the same.

questions.Question: The magnitude of buoyant force depends on the ________ of the fluid.
questions.solution: Solution:		The magnitude of buoyant force depends on the density of the fluid.

questions.Question: A solid needle placed horizontally on the surface of the water floats due to
questions.solution: Solution:		A solid needle placed horizontally on the surface of water floats due to surface tension of water.

questions.Question: Purity of a metal can be determined with the help of
questions.solution: Solution:		Purity of a metal can be determined with the help of Archimedes Principle which makes use of the densities and buoyancy of metals. Finding the density of a metal sample can help to determine its purity. It is most commonly used in the checking the purity of gold.

questions.Question: Buoyancy depends on
questions.optionA: The mass of the liquid displaced
questions.optionC: The depth to which the body is immersed
questions.solution: Solution:		Buoyancy depends on the mass of the liquid displaced.

questions.Question: The rate of flow of electric charge is measured in
questions.solution: Solution:		The rate of flow of electric charge is measured in Ampere.

questions.Question: A device which is used to limit the current in an electrical circuit is called a
questions.solution: Solution:		A fuse places a limit on the amount of current that can be drawn by an electric circuit by opening (blowing or melting) when the current exceeds a preset limit. This protects the circuit and the surroundings from fire or damage in the case of an overload or short circuit.

questions.Question: Materials that allow electricity to flow are called
questions.solution: Solution:		Materials that allow electricity to flow are called conductors.

questions.Question: The fundamental scientific principle in the operation of battery is
questions.solution: Solution:		The electrolyte consists of a solvent (water, an organic liquid, or even a solid) and one or more chemicals that dissociate into ions in the solvent. These ions serve to deliver electrons and chemical matter through the cell interior to balance the flow of electric current outside the cell during cell operation. An electrolyte is a liquid or gel that contains ions and can be decomposed by electrolysis, e.g., that present in a battery. Commonly, electrolytes are solutions of acids, bases, or salts. Electrolyte solutions can also result from the dissolution of some biological (e.g., DNA, polypeptides) and synthetic polymers (e.g., polystyrene sulfonate), termed poly-electrolytes, which contain charged functional groups.

questions.Question: If the current flowing through a circuit is 0.6 A for 6 mins, the amount of electric charge flowing through it is ________
questions.solution: No explanation is given for this questionLet's Discuss on Board

questions.Question: A small gap is left at the joints of rails in a railway track to
questions.optionA: Avoid the tracks being distorted due to seasonal temperature variation
questions.optionB: Avoid the heating of tracks to high temperature
questions.solution: Solution:		A small gap is left at the joints of rails in a railway track to avoid the tracks being distorted due to seasonal temperature variation.

questions.Question: Pipelines in cold countries often burst in winter, because
questions.optionA: Water freezes and expands in its volume
questions.optionB: Temperature of ice is less than that of water
questions.solution: Solution:		Water in pipes freeze in cold countries. Due to the anomalous expansion of water, it expands instead of contacting when there is a fall in temperature below 4°c. So, the water pipes burst due to the excess space consumed by the ice after freezing.

questions.Question: In severe winter, in cold countries water pipes burst because
questions.optionD: Combined effect of all the above three
questions.solution: Solution:		Water in pipes freeze in cold countries. Due to the anomalous expansion of water, it expands instead of contacting when there is a fall in temperature below 4°c. So, the water pipes burst due to the excess space consumed by the ice after freezing.

questions.Question: Railway tracks are banked on curves so that
questions.optionA: Necessary centrifugal force may be obtained from the horizontal component of the weight of the train
questions.optionB: No frictional force may be produced between the tracks and the wheels of the train
questions.optionC: Necessary centripetal force may be obtained from the horizontal component of the weight of the train
questions.optionD: The train may not fall down inwards
questions.solution: Solution:		Railway tracks are banked at the curves so that the necessary centripetal force may be obtained from the horizontal component of the reaction on the train.

questions.Question: The density of the liquid when heated
questions.optionD: May increase of decrease depending on pressure
questions.solution: Solution:		When a liquid is heated, its volume increases and mass of liquid being same density decreases.

questions.Question: The Law of Kepler is related with which among the following ?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Law of Kepler is related with planetary motion.

questions.Question: The term ''equinox' means
questions.optionA: The path which the Earthtakes around the Sun
questions.optionB: The axis of the Earth around which it rotates
questions.optionC: When the day and night are of equal duration
questions.optionD: The time when the Sun seems to be going round and round in the sky in the Arctic but does not go below the horizon
questions.solution: Solution:		The time when the sun crosses the plane of the earth's equator, making night and day of approximately equal length all over the earth and occurring about March 21 (vernal equinox, or spring equinox ) and September 22 (autumnal equinox).

questions.Question: If the earth suddenly stop rotating, the value of "g" will be
questions.solution: Solution:		If the earth stops rotating then the value of 'g' at equator will increase because when the earth rotates the gravity at every point remains uniform and when it stops rotating, the gravity increases as pressure is exerted on only one point at the equator.

questions.Question: If an empty cylinder is half filled with a liquid, its center of gravity is
questions.optionD: Shifted upward or downward depending on the density of the liquid
questions.solution: Solution:		If an empty cylinder is half filled with a liquid, its center of gravity is shifted downwards.

questions.Question: Temperature of distant luminous bodies can be determined by
questions.solution: Solution:		A pyrometer is a type of remote-sensing thermometer used to measure the temperature of a surface. It is a device that from a distance determines the temperature of a luminous surface from the spectrum of the thermal radiation it emits, a process known as pyrometry.

questions.Question: The unit of noise pollution (level) is :
questions.solution: Solution:		Loudness (also called sound pressure level, or SPL) is measured in logarithmic units called decibels (dB).

questions.Question: The speed of sound travel fastest through
questions.solution: Solution:		Of the three phases of matter (gas, liquid, and solid), sound waves travel the slowest through gases, faster through liquids, and fastest through solids.

questions.Question: Compressions and Rarefactions are characteristic of
questions.solution: Solution:		Compressions and Rarefactions are characteristic of longitudinal waves.

questions.Question: Least audible sound for most of the human ear is :
questions.solution: Solution:		Least audible sound for most of the human ear is 0.0002 µ bar.

questions.Question: Hertz is a unit for measuring
questions.solution: Solution:		Frequency is the rate at which current changes direction per second. It is measured in hertz (Hz), an international unit of measure where 1 hertz is equal to 1 cycle per second.

questions.Question: Sound waves in air are
questions.solution: Solution:		Sound waves in air (and any fluid medium) are longitudinal waves because particles of the medium through which the sound is transported vibrate parallel to the direction that the sound wave moves. A vibrating string can create longitudinal waves as depicted in the animation below.

questions.Question: Magnetism at the centre of a bar magnet is
questions.solution: Solution:You see that the field lines near the center are parallel to the length of the bar. Moreover, the density of the field lines on the picture is maximized at the "poles" of the bar magnet and minimized at the center which means that the magnitude of the magnetic field is smallest at the center, too.It's not hard to see why the field lines look approximately as those on the picture above. For an infinitely long magnet, the magnetic field would be fully confined to the cylinder - think of an infinitely long solenoid which essentially has the same magnetic field as a bar magnet. For a bar magnet of a finite length, the field lines ultimately split behind the poles but they're still comparably strong over there.On the other hand, the field outside the bar, and far from the poles, is only nonzero because of some subleading effects; it would vanish for an infinitely long solenoid - that's why the field is so small over there.

questions.Question: It is more difficult to walk on a sandy road than on a concrete road because
questions.optionA: sand is soft and concreter is hard.
questions.optionB: the friction between sand and feet is less than that between concrete and feet.
questions.optionC: the friction between sand and feet is more than that between concrete and feet.
questions.optionD: the sand is grainy but concrete is smooth.
questions.solution: Solution:The friction between sand and feet is less than that between concrete and feet.

questions.Question: Find the maximum velocity for the overturn of a car moving on a circular track of radius 100 m. The co-efficient of friction between the road and tyre is 0.2
questions.solution: Solution:14 m/s.

questions.Question: Of the following properties of a wave, the one that is independent of the other is its
questions.solution: Solution:		The amplitude (A) is independent of other means it is not related to the other quantities.

questions.Question: Thermocouple consists of
questions.solution: Solution:		A thermocouple consists of two dissimilar metals, joined together at one end. When the junction of the two metals is cooled or heated a voltage is produced that can be correlated back to the temperature. Most thermocouple alloys are commonly available as wire.

questions.Question: Water has maximum density at
questions.solution: Solution:		An especially notable irregular maximum density is that of water, which reaches a density peak at 3.98°C (39.16°F) approximately 4oC.

questions.Question: When water freezes its density
questions.solution: Solution:		When water freezes its density decreases. Water at ordinary temperatures contracts and increases in density as it is cooled, like most substances. But at about 4°C it reaches a maximum density and then decreases in density as it approaches the freezing point.

questions.Question: Which of the following are methods of heat transfer?
questions.solution: Solution:		The three types of heat transfer Heat is transfered via solid material (conduction), liquids and gases (convection), and electromagnetical waves (radiation). Heat is usually transfered in a combination of these three types and seldomly occurs on its own.

questions.Question: Heat energy is transferred by conduction whenever molecules
questions.solution: Solution:		Conduction is heat transfer through stationary matter by physical contact.

questions.Question: For a freely falling body, the sum of kinetic energy and potential energy is always
questions.solution: Solution:		The sum total of the potential energy and the kinetic energy of the object during its free fall remains the same, i.e., the total mechanical energy (potential energy + kinetic energy) remains constant. Thus, the law of conservation of energy is not violated.

questions.Question: A body of 4.0 kg is lying at rest. Under the action of a constant force, it gains a speed of 5 m/s. The work done by the force will be ________
If the velocity of a body is halved its kinetic energy ________
questions.solution: Solution:		When velocity is halved, its kinetic energy becomes 1/4th.

questions.Question: Solar energy is converted into chemical energy during
questions.solution: Solution:		Solar energy is converted into chemical energy during photosynthesis.

questions.Question: In which of the following cases, kinetic energy is being used in performing work ?
questions.optionA: Paddling the bicycle to cover a distance
questions.optionB: Driving a car to cover a distance
questions.optionD: Rowing a boat in the lake
questions.solution: Solution:		In driving a car to cover a distance, kinetic energy is being used in performing work.

questions.Question: Land is considered a resource because it
questions.optionD: Costs little or nothing to use
questions.solution: Solution:		Land is considered an important resource because it can be used for various purposes like agriculture, forestry, mining, building houses, roads and setting up of industries. It also serves as a habitat for a variety of flora and fauna.

questions.Question: What is the source of energy for the water cycle?
questions.solution: Solution:		The sun is what makes the water cycle work. The sun provides what almost everything on Earth needs to go—energy, or heat.

questions.Question: Which of the following is a non renewable source of energy ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Coal is a non renewable source of energy.

questions.Question: Which resource is both renewable and inexpensive?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sunlight is the both renewable and inexpensive resource from the given options.

questions.Question: Sources of geothermal power are
questions.solution: Solution:		Sources of geothermal power are water and earth's heat.

questions.Question: Rate of doing work is called
questions.solution: Solution:		In physics, power is the rate of doing work. It is the amount of energy consumed per unit time. The unit of power is the joule per second (J/s), known as the watt.

questions.Question: The energy associated with motion is called
questions.solution: Solution:		The energy associated with motion is called kinetic energy.

questions.Question: The boiling point of water decreases at higher altitudes is due to

questions.Question: Contact force is another name for ________
questions.solution: Solution:		Contact force is another name for Muscular force.

questions.Question: Optical fibre works on which of the following principle of light?
questions.solution: Solution:		The optical fibre is a device which works on the principle of total internal reflection by which light signals can be transmitted from one place to another with a negligible loss of energy.

questions.Question: Which colour of light shows maximum deviation when passed through a prism ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Violet colour of light deviates the maximum during dispersion of white light by the prism as it has least wavelength among all the colours.

questions.Question: The sparkling of a diamond is due to
questions.solution: Solution:		Diamond sparkles because of the total internal reflection that takes place in it, followed by the trapping of the light rays in it. Total internal reflection only takes place when light travels from a denser to a rarer medium.

questions.Question: Stars appear twinkling because of ......... of light.
questions.solution: Solution:		Stars appear twinkling because of scattering of light.

questions.Question: Stars in the sky appear to twinkle due to
questions.solution: Solution:		The twinkling of a star is due to atmospheric refraction of starlight.

questions.Question: Why do birds not have respiratory trouble at the time of flying at high altitude ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Because flying takes a tremendous amount of energy, birds need to get lots of oxygen. The extra air sacs in their lungs help them to keep fresh air flowing in, unlike mammals, where the “old” air within the trachea and mouth (which has low oxygen content and high CO2 levels) in inhaled each time. Birds eliminate this “anatomical dead space” problem by using air sacs.

questions.Question: When a barometer reading suddenly recedes, it indicates that climate–
questions.solution: Solution:		When a barometer reading suddenly recedes, it indicates that climate will be extremely stormy.

questions.Question: When a barometer is rising air pressure is
questions.solution: Solution:		When a barometer is rising air pressure is increasing.

questions.Question: The pressure exerted by a 760 mm column of mercury at 0°C is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The pressure exerted by a 760 mm column of mercury at 0 °C is known as "Pascal".

questions.Question: If a barometric reading is falling, this usually indicates what
questions.solution: Solution:		­A barometer measures air pressure: A "rising" barometer indicates increas­ing air pressure; a "falling" barometer indicates decreasing air pressure.

questions.Question: A gas thermometer is more sensitive than a liquid thermometer because a gas :
questions.solution: Solution:		Since gas expands much more than liquid on changing the temperature. Thus a gas thermometer is more sensitive than liquid thermometer as gas can expand more even in very small change in temperature. So the measurement has to be precised.

questions.Question: What is the SI unit of temperature?
questions.solution: Solution:		Kelvin is the base unit of temperature in the SI system (International System of Units).

questions.Question: Earliest thermometer was developed by
questions.solution: Solution:		Thermoscopes were the earliest types of thermometers and they only showed changes in temperature but didn't show numerical values. One of the first thermoscopes was developed by Italian inventor, Galeleo Galilei in 1593.

questions.Question: The absolute zero is a temperature at which ________
questions.optionA: Molecular motion in a gas would cease

questions.Question: Ice cubes are added to a glass of pure water and a glass of pure alcohol. The ice would be

questions.Question: By how many times are the Electrostatic forces stronger than the Gravitational Forces for a fixed distance?

questions.Question: Which is the point from where an azimuth originates?
questions.solution: Solution:		The azimuth originates at true North i.e, the azimuth originates from the north point. It is a measure of how far an object forms the observer's north point.

questions.Question: The weight of a body acts through the centre of
questions.solution: Solution:		The centre of gravity of a collection of masses is the point where all the weight of the object can be considered to be concentrated. The entire weight acts through the center of gravity instead of acting through the individual masses. In a uniform gravitational field (like the field close to the surface of the Earth) the Centres of Gravity and Mass are in exactly the same place.

questions.Question: If the spinning speed of the earth is increased then the weight of body at the equator
questions.solution: Solution:		If the spinning speed of the earth is increased then the weight of body at the equator decreases.

questions.Question: What does the slope of a velocity time graph represent?
questions.solution: Solution:		The slope of a velocity graph represents the acceleration of the object. So, the value of the slope at a particular time represents the acceleration of the object at that instant.

questions.Question: The slope of a velocity-time graph represents
questions.solution: Solution:		The slope of a velocity graph represents the acceleration of the object. So, the value of the slope at a particular time represents the acceleration of the object at that instant.

questions.Question: What is the change in the angular momentum of a system as per the Law of Conservation of Angular momentum, if the total external torque acting is zero?
questions.solution: Solution:		If net external torque on a system is zero, then the angular momentum of the system can not change. If net external torque on a system is zero, then the angular momentum of the system remains same.

questions.Question: The force that keeps a body in a circular motion called
questions.solution: Solution:		A centripetal force is a net force that acts on an object to keep it moving along a circular path.

questions.Question: It is easier to carry two buckets of water in one hand each, than to carry only one in one hand because
questions.optionB: Centre of gravity falls within the body
questions.optionC: Centre of gravity and centre of equilibrium fall within the feet
questions.optionD: Resultant weight of buckets is zero
questions.solution: Solution:		It is easier to carry two buckets of water in one hand each, than to carry only one in one hand because the centre of gravity and centre of equillibrium fall within the feet. The weight is spaced out more evenly on both the sides of the body than it would be if you had to carry in a single bucket.

questions.Question: The working of a rocket is based on the principle of:
questions.solution: Solution:		Rocket works on the principle of conservation of linear momentum.

questions.Question: A bomb at rest explodes into a large number of tiny fragments. The total momentum of all the fragments
questions.optionB: Depends on the total mass of all the fragments
questions.optionC: Depends on the speeds of various fragments
questions.solution: Solution:		In an explosion, an internal impulse acts in order to propel the parts of a system (often a single object) into a variety of directions. After the explosion, the individual parts of the system (that is often a collection of fragments from the original object) have momentum. If the vector sum of all individual parts of the system could be added together to determine the total momentum after the explosion, then it should be the same as the total momentum before the explosion. Just like in collisions, total system momentum is conserved.

questions.Question: When a body falls from an aeroplane, there is increase in its
questions.solution: Solution:		The energy possessed by a body by virtue of its motion is called kinetic energy. Potential Energy is the energy possessed by virtue of its position or configuration. When a body falls from an aeroplane, there is increase in its acceleration.

questions.Question: Which of the following never occurs singly in nature?
questions.solution: Solution:		According to Newton, force can never occur singly in nature; it is the mutual interaction between two bodies. This formed the basis of Newton's Third Law of motion which states: “To every action, there is always an equal and opposite reaction.” Forces always occur in pairs.

questions.Question: The moment of inertia of a body does not depend upon

questions.solution: Solution:		Newton's first law of motion is sometimes referred to as the law of inertia. An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.

questions.Question: If you look into a mirror and find that the image (your reflection) is smaller than you, then the type of the mirror is:

questions.Question: A man stands on the pan of a balance holding a fish in his right hand and bucket of water in his left hand. If he transfers the fish into the bucket, the total weight on the pan
questions.solution: Solution:		Before transferring the fish, the position is the man with the fish and the bucket of water. Thus to knowwhether there is any change in weight, it is enough to consider whether there is any change in weight when the fish in air is transferred into the water. questions.solution: Solution:		A body moving in a circular path with a constant speed has a constant kinetic energy.

It is that point that moves when forces are applied on the body.

questions.Question: Why is weightlessness experienced while orbiting the earth in space ships ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Earth-orbiting astronauts are weightless for the same reasons that riders of a free-falling amusement park ride or a free-falling elevator are weightless. They are weightless because there is no external contact force pushing or pulling upon their body.

questions.Question: In the case of bodies falling under gravity which of the following remains constant at a given place?
questions.solution: Solution:		In the case of bodies falling under gravity accelerationremains constant at a given place.

questions.Question: The instrument used to see the distant objects on the Earth is
questions.solution: Solution:		The instrument used to see the distant objects on the Earth is Terrestrial telescope.

questions.Question: Intensity of gravitational field of earth is maximum at
questions.solution: Solution:		A perfect sphere of spherically uniform density (density varies solely with distance from centre) would produce a gravitational field of uniform magnitude at all points on its surface, always pointing directly towards the sphere’s centre. However, the Earth deviates slightly from this ideal, and there are consequently slight deviations in both the magnitude and direction of gravity across its surface. Furthermore, the net force exerted on an object due to the Earth, called “effective gravity” or “apparent gravity”, varies due to the presence of other factors, such as inertial response to the Earth’s rotation. A scale or plumb bob measures only this effective gravity. The major reason for the difference in gravity at different latitudes is that the Earth’s equatorial bulge (itself also caused by inertia) causes objects at the Equator to be farther from the planet’s centre than objects at the poles. Because the force due to gravitational attraction between two bodies (the Earth and the object being weighed) varies inversely with the square of the distance between them, an object at the Equator experiences a weaker gravitational pull than an object at the poles.

questions.Question: If cream is removed from milk, its density
questions.solution: Solution:		The density of pure fresh milk being on the average 1.032, while the density of fat globules is about 0.86. It follows that the removal of cream will increase the density, while the addition of water will decrease it.

questions.Question: A falling drop of rain water acquires the spherical shape due to
questions.solution: Solution:		Raindrops start out as round high in the atmosphere as water collects on dust and smoke particles in clouds. But as raindrops fall, they lose their rounded shape. A raindrop falling through the atmosphere forms as a roughly spherical structure due to the surface tension of water. This surface tension is the “skin” of a body of water that makes the molecules stick together. The cause is the weak hydrogen bonds that occur between water molecules. On smaller raindrops, the surface tension is stronger than in larger drops. The reason is the flow of air around the drop. Air flow on the bottom of the water drop is greater than the airflow at the top.

questions.Question: Why the needle of iron swims on water surface when it is kept gently ?
questions.optionA: It will remain under the water, when it will displace more water than its weight
questions.optionB: The density of needle is less than that of water
questions.solution: Solution:		According to Archimedes principle and we can note that the amount of water displaced by a needle is lesser than the amount of water moved out by the needle (that is displacement of the needle). So the needle initially stays on the surface of the water and then sinks into the water. Surface tension is a contractive tendency of the surface of a liquid that allows it to resist an external force. It is revealed, for example, in the floating of some objects on the surface of water, even though they are denser than water, and in the ability of some insects (e.g. water striders) to run on the water surface. This property is caused by cohesion of similar molecules, and is responsible for many of the behaviors of liquids.

questions.Question: Rise of oil a wick is due to
questions.solution: Solution:		The phenomenon of rise or fall of liquid in a capillary tube is called capillarity. Oil rises through a wick due to capillarity. The narrow pores in the threads of a wick act like tiny capillaries, through which oil rises. Capillary action is the result of adhesion and surface tension.

questions.Question: Bubbles of air rise up through liquids due to
questions.optionC: Air current over the liquid and buoyancy
questions.solution: Solution:		Bubbles of air rise up through liquids due to viscosity and buoyancy.

questions.Question: Which of the following is a result of Surface tension ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Capillary action is the result of adhesion and surface tension. Adhesion of water to the walls of a vessel will cause an upward force on the liquid at the edges and result in a meniscus which turns upward. The surface tension acts to hold the surface intact, so instead of just the edges moving upward, the whole liquid surface is dragged upward.

questions.Question: A liquid disturbed by stirring comes to rest due to
questions.solution: Solution:		A liquid disturbed by stirring comes to rest due to viscosity.

questions.Question: A capillary tube is partially dipped vertically in a vessel containing water. Due to capillarity water rises in the tube. The height of water rise in the tube can be increased by
questions.optionA: Decreasing the radius of the capillary tube
questions.optionB: Increasing the radius of the capillary tube
questions.optionC: Increasing the height of water in the vessel
questions.solution: Solution:		The water rise in a capillary tube dipped in water is such that the weight of water in the tube above the surface of water in the vessel is equal to (balances) the upward force due to surface tension. So it is clear that if the the bore (radius) to the tube is decreased, the height of the water column in it must be greater.So, (a) is correct

questions.Question: Oil rises up the wick in a lamp because
questions.optionB: Of the diffusion of oil through the wick
questions.solution: Solution:		It is because of the capillary action phenomenon because of which oil rise up the wick in a lamp. Capillary action, or capillarity, is the ability of a liquid to flow in narrow spaces without the assistance of, and in opposition to external forces like gravity. The effect can be seen in the drawing up of liquids between the hairs of a paint-brush, in a thin tube, in porous materials such as paper, in some non-porous materials such as liquefied carbon fiber, or in a cell. It occurs because of inter-molecular attractive forces between the liquid and solid surrounding surfaces.

questions.Question: An ice block with a piece of lead embeded in it floats in water. If ice melts the water level
questions.solution: Solution:		If r1 is the density of the lead piece of volume v, the volume of water displaced by the ice block and the lead piece while floating is Vw = (V–v) r1 + v r1. When the ice melts, the lead piece sinks in water since r1 is greater than the density of water. The water produced by the melted ice has the volume (V-v) r1 and the volume displaced by the lead piece is v. So, the total volume of the water produced by ice and that displaced by the lead piece is V w1 = (V–v) r1+ v r1< V w. So, the water level goes down.

questions.Question: Vegetables are cooked in lesser time by adding a pinch of salt while cooking because
questions.optionB: Latent heat of vaporization of water decreases
questions.optionC: Latent heat of vaporization of water increases
questions.solution: Solution:		Adding salt raises the boiling point of water, which allows food to cook at higher temperature. The higher the temperature, the higher the rate of heat transfer between the food and water, thus it cooks more quickly.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not an aerosol?
questions.solution: Solution:		Some of the examples of aerosols are fog, dust, smoke, geyser steam etc. They can be natural or anthropogenic. Mud is not an aerosol.

questions.Question: What is the process of conversion of solid state directly to gaseous state called?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sublimation is the process of transformation directly from the solid phase to the gaseous phase, without passing through an intermediate liquid phase.

questions.Question: Solids have definite shapes.This is because
questions.optionA: The forces of cohesion of the molecules within are very much less in them
questions.optionB: The forces of cohesion are very large
questions.optionC: The forces of adhesion are large
questions.optionD: The forces of adhesion are less
questions.solution: Solution:		Any matter that is a solid has a definite shape and a definite volume. The molecules in a solid are in fixed positions and are close together. Although the molecules can still vibrate, they cannot move from one part of the solid to another part. As a result, a solid does not easily change its shape or its volume.

questions.Question: The amount of matter in a ball of steel is its :
questions.solution: Solution:		The amount of matter in a ball of steel is its mass.

questions.Question: A wheel-barrow is an example of
questions.solution: Solution:		A wheel barrow is an example of second class lever as the load is between the fulcrum and effort,hence it is a second class lever.

In this case, the pulley helps in lifting the bucket full of water upwards.

questions.Question: A fixture is defined as a device which

questions.Question: Two metallic wires made from copper have same length but the radius of wire 1 is half of that of wire 2. The resistance of wire 1 is R. If both the wires are joined together in series, the total resistance becomes
questions.solution: Solution:		So, resistance of Wire 2 is R/4 as radius is half of wire 1, so area would be 4 times of wire 1.Now for resistance in series. R= R1 + R2.Therefore, Final R= R + R/4 = 5R/4

questions.Question: As we go from Equator to North pole the value of ''g', the acceleration due to gravity
questions.solution: Solution:		As, the earth is not a perfect sphere, the gravity keeps on changing as we move from one place to another. questions.Question: A car accelerates uniformly from 18 kmph to 72 kmph in 5 s. The acceleration of the car (in m/s2) is:

questions.Question: Hot water is poured simultaneously in four metallic tumblers painted outside with different points. After some time the water will be found to have cooled most in the tumbler painted.
questions.solution: No explanation is given for this questionLet's Discuss on Board

questions.Question: Which of the following criterion is used for any metal to be used as a cooking material ?
questions.solution: Solution:		A metal to be used as a cooking material should have less thermal conductivity.

questions.Question: Heat from the sun reaches earth by the process of
questions.solution: Solution:		Radiation is the transfer of heat energy through space by electromagnetic radiation. Most of the electromagnetic radiation that comes to the earth from the sun is invisible.

questions.Question: Ocean currents are an example of
questions.solution: Solution:		Ocean currents are an example of convection.

questions.Question: What type of heat transfer is boiling water?
questions.solution: Solution:		When a pot of water is placed on the stove to boil, conduction heat warms up the pot, which then heats the water molecules inside. As these molecules heat, convection causes them to move away from the interior of the pot as they are replaced by cooler molecules.

questions.Question: Mist is caused by
questions.solution: Solution:		Mist is a phenomenon caused by small droplets of water suspended in air. It can occur as part of natural weather or volcanic activity, and is common in cold air above warmer water, in exhaled air in the cold, and in a steam room of a sauna. It can also be created artificially with aerosol canisters if the humidity conditions are right. The only difference between mist and fog is visibility. Mist usually occurs near the shores, and is often associated with fog. Mist can be as high as mountain tops when extreme temperatures are low. Freezing mist is similar to freezing fog, only the density is less and the visibility greater.

questions.Question: Which colour is the complementary colour of yellow ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Blue is the complementary colour of yellow.

questions.Question: In sunlight a rose appears red. In green light, the same rose appears
questions.solution: Solution:		Any object which allows light to pass through it is known as a transparent object. The colour of any transparent object is the colour of the light transmitted by it. A red rose appears red in white light because it absorbs all colours except red. However, when seen in green light, it looks black because the red colour of the rose is absorbed by the green light.

questions.Question: When the Sun is near the horizon during the morning or evening, it appears reddish. The phenomenon that is responsible for this observation is
questions.solution: Solution:		The red colour in the sky at sunset (and sunrise) is due to an effect called Rayleigh scattering. There is a similar form of scattering called Mie scattering which is responsible for the white colour of clouds.

questions.Question: Which combination of colour is the most convenient during day and night time ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Red and green is the most convenient combination during day and night time because of very precise visibility.

questions.Question: Reading of a barometer going down is an indication of
questions.solution: Solution:		Barometer is instrument which is used to measure to pressure. A slow downfall of reading suggests a low pressure area is passing in a nearby region, it may rain. If the reading is going down very fast then its an indication of storm (within 5-6 hours).

questions.Question: Increased wind speed is accompanied by a reduced air ________
questions.solution: Solution:		The increased wind speed is accompanied by low/reduced air pressure.

questions.Question: A vacuum cleaner works on the principle of pressure difference. On the moon it will
questions.optionA: Work as efficiently as on the earth
questions.solution: Solution:		Vacuum cleaners work by creating a lower pressure just inside the opening which touches the floor. Because there is no, or very little, atmosphere on the moon, we can't create a lower or higher gas pressure inside and outside the machine, so dirt cannot be sucked up from the ground.

questions.Question: Middle latitude cyclones are fueled by?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cyclones are fueled by the temperature differences (hence pressure gradients) that exist along frontal boundaries. They are usually strongest during cold months when temperature differences between air masses can be most extreme.

questions.Question: Skating on ice is possible because
questions.optionA: The surface of ice is smooth
questions.optionC: The pressure on the ice due to skate melts the ice by lowering its melting point forming a thin film of water
questions.optionD: The pressure on the ice due to skate raises its melting point
questions.solution: Solution:		Skating on ice is possible because the pressure on the ice due to skate melts the ice by lowering its melting point forming a thin film of water.

questions.Question: The number of waves per second in a sound is called ________ of that sound.
questions.solution: Solution:		The number of waves per second in a sound is called frequency of that sound.

questions.Question: Sound waves do not show the phenomenon of
questions.solution: Solution:		As sound waves are longitudinal waves, they don't exhibit Polarization phenomenon, which is exhibited by the transverse wave only.

questions.Question: Speed of sound is maximum in which among the following?
questions.solution: Solution:		We know that, in solids all the particles are packed together and hence sound can travel from one to one very fast. Hence, speed of sound is maximum in solids and decreases from solids to liquids and liquids to gases. Sound can't travel through vacuum.

questions.Question: The ringing of an electric bell in an enclosed evacuated glass bell jar is not heard outside because
questions.optionA: The ringing is not loud enough
questions.optionB: The glass of the bell jar absorbs the sound waves
questions.optionC: The bell jar is too small
questions.optionD: There is no air or any other gas in the bell jar
questions.solution: Solution:		The ringing of an electric bell in an enclosed evacuated glass bell jar is not heard outside because there is no air or any other gas in the bell jar.

questions.Question: What is the full form of "RADAR" ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Radio Detecting and Ranging is the full form of "RADAR".

questions.Question: The three famous law of Kepler is related to
questions.solution: Solution:		The three famous law of Kepler is related to planetary motion.

questions.Question: In Astrophysics, what name is given to a hypothetical hole in outer space from which stars and energy emerge?
questions.solution: Solution:		A White Hole is a hypothetical hole in outer space from which energy, stars, and other celestial matter emerge or explode. It is a theoretical celestial object into which matter is funneled from a black hole.

questions.Question: If there were no gravity, which of the following will not be there for a fluid?
questions.solution: Solution:		Archimedes' upward thrust will be absent for a fluid, if there were no gravity.

questions.Question: Number of lattices in the orthorhombic system is
questions.solution: Solution:		Number of lattices in the orthorhombic system is 7.

questions.Question: The term ''Isoneph' indicates the lines of equal
questions.solution: Solution:		An isoneph is a line indicating equal cloud cover or equal cloudiness. Variations in the degrees of slope, temperature, occurrence of rainfall, may be represented by drawing the lines of equal values on a map. All such maps are termed as Isopleth Map. The word Isopleth is derived from ‘Iso’ meaning equal and ‘pleth’ means lines. Thus, an imaginary line, which joins the places of equal values, is referred as Isopleth. The more frequently drawn isopleths include Isotherm (equal temperature), Isobar (equal pressure), Isohyets (equal rainfall), Isonephs (equal cloudiness), Isohels (equal sunshine), contours (equal heights), Isobaths (equal depths), Isohaline (equal salinity), etc.

questions.Question: How much calorie of energy is released by a boiled egg ?
questions.solution: Solution:		77-78 calories are released in a large size boiled egg.

questions.Question: A stone is dropped from the roof of a house towards the ground. The kinetic energy of the stone will be maximum:
questions.optionB: When it is just on the half-way
questions.optionC: Just before it touches the ground
questions.solution: Solution:		When an object reaches the ground it has its maximum value of kinetic energy just before touching the ground. Since kinetic energy + potential energy= Constant; so on reaching ground the potential energy of an object becomes zero (0). The kinetic energy on reaching ground becomes maximum.

questions.Question: A 4 kg object is moving horizontally with a speed of 5 m/s. To increase its speed to 10 m/s, the amount of net work required to be done on this object is:
questions.solution: Solution:		m=4 kg u=5 m/s v=10 m/s according to work energy theorem w=1/2*m*(v2-u2) w=1/2*4*(102-52) w=1/2*4*(100-25) w=2×75 w=150 J

questions.Question: Gasoline is useful in cars because it has
questions.solution: Solution:		Gasoline is a colorless petroleum-derived flammable liquid that is used primarily as a fuel in spark-ignited internal combustion engines. It consists mostly of organic compounds obtained by the fractional distillation of petroleum, enhanced with a variety of additives. It is also called as Petrol. It has chemical potential energy, in combustion it is turned into light, sound, heat and kinetic energy.

questions.Question: Electric Motor converts ________ energy to mechanical energy
questions.solution: Solution:		Electric Motor converts electrical energy to mechanical energy.

questions.Question: If an ordinary glass tube and a glass capillary tube are both dipped in a beaker of water, water rises in
questions.solution: Solution:		The rise or fall of liquid due to capillarity in a beaker of water depends upon the radius of the bore of the tube (s) which is/are dipped into it. The narrower the bore of the tube, the greater is the rise or fall of the liquid in the tube. So in this case, water will rise in both the glass tube and the glass capillary tube.

questions.Question: Surface tension in a liquid is due to :
questions.solution: Solution:		Surface tension could be defined as the property of the surface of a liquid that allows it to resist an external force, due to the cohesive nature of the water molecules.

questions.Question: A boat loaded with rocks floats in the middle of a swimming pool. A man in the boat throws the rocks overboard. The level of water in the pool will
questions.solution: Solution:		Let M and m grams be the mass of boat + rock in it. By law of floatation(M+m) grams of water will be displaced. This has a volume of (M+m)cc. That means the level of water in pool has risen up by (M+m)cc with the boat + rock when it is floating. If the rocks in the boat are thrown not into the pool but outside, the weight left is only M grams the weight of the boat. This will have displaced M cc of water only i.e less water than in the case of loaded boat. But if the rocks are put in the water in the pool and not outside, then the water in the pool will rise not only by M cc on account of empty boat but also by a volume of the stone put into it. This volume will be m/d where m is the mass of rock and d density of rock.Now m/d is< m. Thus the total rise will be (M+m/d) which is < M + m.

questions.Question: The oil in the wick of an oil lamp rises up due to:
questions.solution: Solution:		The oil in the wick of an oil lamp rises up due to capillary action. This effect is due to surface tension of liquids. The wick here acts as a capillary tube.

questions.Question: Fog is an example of
questions.solution: Solution:		Fog is tiny water droplets or ice crystals suspended in the air at or near the Earth's surface. Hence, fog is an example of a colloidal system liquid dispersed in gas.

questions.Question: A fresh egg when placed in salt water will
questions.optionA: Sink and go to the bottom
questions.optionB: Sink but will not go to the bottom
questions.solution: Solution:		Adding salt to the water increases the density of the solution because the salt increases the mass without changing the volume very much. When enough salt is added to the water, the saltwater solution's density becomes higher than the egg's, so the egg will then float.

questions.Question: Burns caused by steam are much severe than those caused by boiling water because
questions.optionA: Steam pierces through the pores of body quickly
questions.optionC: Steam is gas and engulfs the body quickly
questions.solution: Solution:		Steam produces more severe burns than boiling water even though both are at 100oC because steam contains more heat, in the form of latent heat, than boiling water.

questions.Question: Which of the following has got more heat capacity ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Heat capacity (usually denoted by a capital C, often with subscripts), or thermal capacity, is the measurable physical quantity that characterizes the amount of heat required to change a substance’s temperature by a given amount. In the International System of Units (SI), heat capacity is expressed in units of joule(s) (J) per Kelvin (K). Among iron piece, water, gold piece and benzene; water has the maximum heat capacity i.e. 4.1813 j/k.

questions.Question: Which of the following produces more severe burns ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Steam produces more severe burns than boiling water even though both are at 100oC because steam contains more heat, in the form of latent heat, than boiling water.

questions.Question: Heat stored in water vapour is
questions.solution: Solution:		When air is cooled and water vapour condenses to form water liquid, energy is released as water particles 'give up' some of their energy in order to slow down and move closer together again. The same is true when liquid water freezes to become ice. This energy is also called latent heat.

questions.Question: Hydraulic machines work under the Principle of :
questions.solution: Solution:		The hydraulic system works on the principle of Pascal's law which says that the pressure in an enclosed fluid is uniform in all the directions.

questions.Question: Alcohol is more volatile than water because ________ is lower than water.
questions.solution: Solution:		Alcohol is more volatile than water because it boiling point is lower than water.

questions.Question: A manometer is used to measure
questions.solution: Solution:		Manometers are precision instruments that are used to measure pressure, which is the force exerted by a gas or liquid per unit surface area owing to the effects of the weight of that gas or liquid from gravity.

questions.Question: Anemometer is used to measure
questions.solution: Solution:		An anemometer is an instrument that measures wind speed and wind pressure. Anemometers are important tools for meteorologists, who study weather patterns. They are also important to the work of physicists, who study the way air moves.

questions.Question: The instrument used to measure the speed of the wind is
questions.solution: Solution:		The instrument used to measure the speed of the wind is anemometer.

questions.Question: An optically plane surface reflects a beam of light
questions.optionA: As a parallel beam in one direction
questions.optionB: As diffused beams in all directions
questions.optionC: As parallel beams in all directions
questions.optionD: As a diffused beam in one direction
questions.solution: Solution:		An optically plane surface reflects a beam of light as a parallel beam in one direction. The set of incident rays are reflected as a set of rays. This type of reflection of a set of rays is called Specular Reflection.

questions.Question: The focal length of a concave mirror with a radius of curvature of 20.0 cm is :
questions.solution: Solution:		Let us assume f is focal length R is radius of curvature According to the formula R = 2f f = R/2 = 20/2 = 10 cm

questions.Question: The type of mirrors used in the headlamp of cars is
questions.solution: Solution:		A concave mirror is used in the headlight of a car. The reason being that a concave mirror is a converging mirror as opposed to a convex mirror which is a diverging mirror. In headlights the bulb is kept at the focus of the mirror.

questions.Question: Shaving mirror is
questions.solution: Solution:		A shaving mirror gives an enlarged image. The mirror is concave. You must have your face within the focal length of the mirror, to get an upright and enlarged image.

questions.Question: What changes will happen to a bowl of ice and water kept at exactly zero degree Celsius ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Fresh water cooled to zero degree Celsius and subjected to additional loss of heat energy normally will freeze. A mixture of fresh water and ice has an equilibrium temperature of zero degree Celsius. Adding heat to the mixture causes ice to melt whereas removing heat causes water to freeze. So, no change will happen.
